Looks like this is a check that rclone should be doing for itself now...

Fancy sending a Pull Request?

> Fancy sending a Pull Request?

I wish I could, but all that I know is `./configure && make` :smile: 
Hope someone else will.
nonempty really should never ever be used as it allows for over mounting and hiding things. A bad option and you should really stay way from it.
nonempty was removed from mainline libfuse because the default behavior of mount is `nonempty`.

> nonempty really should never ever be used as it allows for over mounting and hiding things. A bad option and you should really stay way from it.

Agreed!  However it is useful if you ever want to use rclone in an autofs mount - if you don't use it there then you get an infinite loop.

> Agreed! However it is useful if you ever want to use rclone in an autofs mount - if you don't use it there then you get an infinite loop.

@ncw I don't thunk so.

I have recently run tests with rclone mount and systemd autofs on ubuntu xenial using rclone mount wrapper from https://github.com/rclone/rclone/wiki/rclone-fstab-mount-helper-script

All tests were run on Ubuntu Xenial amd64 with latest updates.

The test matrix included:
- remote with a file vs empty remote
- fstab with `allow-non-empty` (passed to rclone mount via $trans) vs without this option
- backrounding done using shell's ampersand (`&`) in wrapper vs `rclone mount --daemon ...` without ampersand
- with or without x-systemd.automount in fstab

Results:
- `--daemon` just hangs, always (must be a flag-related bug in rclone, I added a comment in the wiki)
- empty remote just hangs - obviously due to "total 0" loop in wrapper (I added a comment in the wiki)
- `allow-non-empty` does not affect anything in the test; mounts (with or without `x-systemd.automount`) work correctly with or without this option
Interesting @ivandeex - what do you think is different from #3246 - in that I was pretty convinced that not using --allow-non-empty was causing some kind of loopy funkiness with autofs.

Probably user started experimenting with an empty remote and buggy `while ... ls ... 'total 0' ...` loop in the wrapper looped forever, then user created an unnoticed test file while experimenting with fstab options. User (or you) decided that allow-non-empty is the fix.

Just a wild guess...

The loop can be slightly enhanced by using `ls -l -A $mountpoint` so that it sees dotted files too. But this leaves a big hole - no bash loop can properly tell an empty mount from empty unmounted point. 

The proper solution is a **fix** of the `--daemon`/`--daemon-timeout` option. It should fork a background rclone process, wait for "mount successful" signal from child with timeout and exit with appropriate code. This will render looping in the wrapper unneeded, just canonical "exec rclone mount --daemon translated_options...".

Btw according to this https://github.com/libfuse/libfuse/commit/0bef21e8543dda7f02b5f4cb3008a7292d249842#diff-a136a3ab0403c35496be1955335be9d9R8, now libfuse behaves as if "nonempty" is provided everytime. If it were the fix you'd only have to remove the wiki comment about allow-non-empty ;)
Actually "nonempty" is never provided, so [this](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/v1.49.3/cmd/cmount/mount.go#L77) needs to be removed.

> The proper solution is a **fix** of the `--daemon`/`--daemon-timeout` option. It should fork a background rclone process, wait for "mount successful" signal from child with timeout and exit with appropriate code. This will render looping in the wrapper unneeded, just canonical "exec rclone mount --daemon translated_options...".

Forking is a bit difficult in go in general but doing that might be possible... We'd probably have to write a file or something like that.

Here is the code if you want to have a look

https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/master/cmd/mountlib/daemon_unix.go

Note that `--daemon-timeout` is an OSXFUSE feature for extending the time the kernel waits for rclone to respond, so not strictly relevant here.

issue.title: Replace close() call in Flush() with writeback of dirty data to backing storage (Fix for #3381)

<!--
Thank you very much for contributing code or documentation to rclone! Please
fill out the following questions to make it easier for us to review your

You do not need to check all the boxes below all at once, feel free to take
your time and add more commits. If you're done and ready for review, please
check the last box.
-->

#### What is the purpose of this change?

<!--
Describe the changes here
-->

vfs: move writeback of dirty data out of close() method into its own method (FlushWrites) and remove close() call from Flush()
    
If a file handle is duplicated with dup() and the duplicate handle is flushed, rclone will go ahead and close the file, making the original file handle stale. This change removes the close() call from Flush() and replaces it with FlushWrites() so that the file only gets closed when Release() is called. The new FlushWrites method takes care of actually writing the file back to the underlying storage.

Fixes #3381

#### Was the change discussed in an issue or in the forum before?

https://github.com/rclone/rclone/issues/3381
https://forum.rclone.org/t/rclone-mount-vfs-cache-doesnt-appear-to-handle-dup-calls-gracefully/11030

```
[1] 59677

[1]   Exit 1                  rclone mount --max-read-ahead 1024k --allow-other dediseedbox: /mnt/disks/dediseedbox
root@UNRAIDSERVER:~# 2019/10/15 00:04:26 mount helper error: fusermount: unknown option 'nonempty'
2019/10/15 00:04:26 Fatal error: failed to mount FUSE fs: fusermount: exit status 1
```

That is saying your fusermount doesn't support the FUSE option `nonempty` which rclone attempts to set when using `--allow-non-empty`.

This is exactly what this issue needs to fix.

In the mean time just make sure your mountpoint is empty of files.

**Update**: what version of libfuse are you using?
